description: From Middle English veyne, borrowed from Anglo-Norman veine, from Latin vēna (“a blood-vessel; vein; artery”) of uncertain origin. See vēna for more. Doublet of vena. Displaced native edre, from ǣdre (whence edder).

entries.meaning: (anatomy) A blood vessel that transports blood from the capillaries back to the heart.
(in the plural) The entrails of a shrimp.
(botany) In leaves, a thickened portion of the leaf containing the vascular bundle.
(zoology) The nervure of an insect’s wing.

definitionGroups.group: A stripe or streak of a different colour or composition in materials such as wood, cheese, marble or other rocks.

entries.meaning: (geology) A sheetlike body of crystallized minerals within a rock.
(figurative) A topic of discussion; a train of association, thoughts, emotions, etc.

examples: The play is in a satirical vein.

entries.meaning: A fissure, cleft, or cavity, as in the earth or other substance.
examples: I took another Prism therefore which was free from Veins

verbs.description: vein (third-person singular simple present veins, present participle veining, simple past and past participle veined)

entries.meaning: To mark with veins or a vein-like pattern.
examples: […]  as he ceased from that wild imprecation, a faint flash of lightning veined the remote horizon, and a low clap of thunder rumbled afar off, echoing among the hills  […]
